columnTopHeaders.headerLeft: HEI generation/ dissemination of development relevant evidence
columnTopHeaders.headerCenter: Ability and Commitment of policy and development organizations to apply evidence
columnTopHeaders.headerRight: Use of research for more effective programs and policy

columnHeadersLeft.title: [O-HEI1] HEI institutional capacity to manage, support, and conduct high quality development-relevant research has increased
[O-HEI2] Capacity of researchers to conduct high quality development-relevant research has increased
[O-HEI3] Capacity of researchers and/or institutions to translate research into (use) practice, program, and policy
[O-HEI4] HEI research networks expanded to identify and solve development challenges

columnHeadersRight.title: [O-PDO1] Linkage between research networks and policy/ development community has improved
[O-PDO2] Linkages between research networks and private sector community increased
[O-PDO3] Capacity of development actors to integrate evidence in programming increased
[O-PDO4] Commitment of development actors to integrate evidence in programming increased
[O-RU1] Translation of research into programs and practice has increased
[O-RU2] Translation of research into policy has increased

Building Research Collaborations.title: BRC1 - Between development organizations and scientific, research, and academic institutions, both domestic and international
Building Research Collaborations.description: Multi-stakeholder partnerships meant to bring together research producers, such as academic institutions, and research users such as development organizations.

Building Research Collaborations.title: BRC2 - Between individual researchers, both domestic and international
Building Research Collaborations.description: A researcher partnership includes any collaboration between research scientists in search of a solution to a common challenge/ question

Building Research Collaborations.title: BRC3 - Between individual policymakers/practitioners and researchers
Building Research Collaborations.description: This refers to formal and informal partnerships intended to inform on, and promote the use of, research findings

Building Research Collaborations.title: BRC4 - Between scientific, research, and academic institutions, both domestic and international
Building Research Collaborations.description: This includes formalized collaborations and regular partnerships between institutions and might take the form of joint program funding, student exchange relationships, shared resources and science diplomacy initiatives

Building Research Collaborations.title: BRC5 - In Partnership with Community-Level Actors

Capacity Building for HEIS.title: CB-HEI1 - In project management and research administration
Capacity Building for HEIS.description: Project management and research administration includes all aspects of budgeting, grants managment, staff management, reporting and similar

Capacity Building for HEIS.title: CB-HEI2 - In curriculum development, pedagogy, or other teaching and trainings skills

Capacity Building for Researchers.title: CB-RE1 - In conceptualization and design of policy- and social impact-relevant research
Capacity Building for Researchers.description: In addition to a traditional problem hypothesis, social impact-relevant research incorporates elements of operations research or implementation science, which is the scientific study of barriers to and methods of promoting the systematic application of research findings in practice, including in public policy. Conceptualization and design of this research is often done in collaboration with development practicioners and can include methods such as Co-creation.

Capacity Building for Researchers.title: CB-RE2 - Through research translation training (also with HEIs)
Capacity Building for Researchers.description: Training on research translation includes any activities that increase the ability of researchers to put the results of their work into use

Capacity Building for Researchers.title: CB-RE3 - Through specialized research implementation and translation technical assistance
Capacity Building for Researchers.description: Research implementation and translation technical assistance refers to tools and services provided by outside experts to researchers in order to augment research findings in audience-targeted ways and to promote the systematic application of those research findings in practice, including in public policy.

Capacity Building for Researchers.title: CB-RE4 - Through creation of centers of excellence
Capacity Building for Researchers.description: A center of excellence is a team, a shared facility or an entity (here intended to refer to academic teams, facilities, or entities) that provides leadership, best practices, research, support, resources and/or training for a focus area.

Capacity Building for Researchers.title: CB-RE5 - On use of advanced digital tools
Capacity Building for Researchers.description: Advanced digital tools refer to 21st century hardware and software technologies. These include applications of artificial intelligence such as machine learning and natural language processing but also new uses for 20th century hardware that open up new methods of data collection and analysis, such as Internet of Things, Social Media Data Automation, Geographic Information Systems, and Big Data Analytics. Note: Building this capacity very often comes with pre-established infrastructure (power, broadband, cellular data) requirements.

Capacity Building for Policy Makers and.title: CB-PP1 - On data literacy and use
CB-PP3 - Through specialized technical assistance on research translation and use
Capacity Building for Policy Makers and.description: Training, advisory services, and collaborative activities to support policy-makers and practicioners with a range of research-related activities. This includes identifying research questions, accessing research, contracting and managing research, and interpreting and translating research.  Illustrative activities include training policy makers and practicioners in designing and managing research projects; training and providing tools for practicioners to access research, embedding scientific research experts in government agencies or in government working groups and commitees in order facilitate evidence informed policy. (More holistic , integrated approaches than 15 & 16))

Resource Provision.title: RP1 - To individual researchers in the form of monetary support
RP2 - To individual researchers in the form of equipment and other in-kind support
RP3 - To academic and other scientific institutions in the form of monetary support
RP4 - To academic, research, and other scientific institutions in the form of equipment, infrastructure, and other in-kind support
RP5 - For joint funding of domestic and international collaborations
RP7 - For internship and work-study opportunities

Ecosystem Strengthening.title: ES1 - For coordinating research across organizations through R&D councils, science academies, and similar entities
Ecosystem Strengthening.description: R&D councils refer to working groups whose purpose focuses on the increased commitment for the use and application of research in decision making in public and private sector organizations. For example support for the establishment of national councils of science and technology. At the institutional level, establishing organization-level R&D councils.

Ecosystem Strengthening.title: ES2 - For HEI-based innovation accelerators and incubators
Ecosystem Strengthening.description: Innovation accelerators and incubators are hubs that house teams focused on introducing new practices and products that are socially relevant and have a market. These hubs provide essential support for taking research to pilot and if successful, implemention and scale.

Ecosystem Strengthening.title: ES3 - To create and/or strengthen research networks
Ecosystem Strengthening.description: A research network is a group of researchers who are united in purpose but who aren't necessarily engaged in an ongoing collaborative partnership

Ecosystem Strengthening.title: ES4 - Through HEI -based tech transfer/commercialization programs
Ecosystem Strengthening.description: Strengthening tech transfer includes efforts designed to put in place HEI policy, staff, and procedures towards fostering and supporting a culture of research for commercialization and can also include developing agreements between HEIs and host government bodies to ensure intellectual property protection and standard oversight procedures.

Ecosystem Strengthening.title: E5S - By facilitating the design, implementation, and management of scientific research-related policies
Ecosystem Strengthening.description: Scientific research-related policies are laws, regulations, standards and guidelines that govern the role and implementation of science and research in domestic and international affairs.  These policies provide guidance to a variety of actors: the private sector, state and local governments, the science and higher education communities, and even other nations. Policies include patent and trademark regulations, technology transfer policies and programs, standards of scientific integrity, public access  and open data .

Research Dissemination.title: RD1 - Through face-to-face events
Research Dissemination.description: Face-to-face events are research and information sharing gatherings that are not explicitly designed for the purpose of directing future actiivites. These include panels, summits, conferences and similar. These events can be in-person or virtual.

Research Dissemination.title: RD2 - Through workshops and problem-solving events
Research Dissemination.description: Workshops and problem-solving events include any gathering of researchers and other develoment stakeholders to present research evidence and discuss how it might be used to inform process. Workshops and problem-solving events result in recommendations/ strategies for future work and attendee commitments to action. These can include Hack-a-thons and so-called agenda setting events

Research Dissemination.title: RD3 - On collaborative platforms
Research Dissemination.description: Collaborative platforms are those that encourage and facilitate constructive discourse on scientific research, application and similar topics. These include social media platforms, bi-directional engagement forums, communities of practices, and other venues for thought exchange.

Research Dissemination.title: RD4 - On websites for disseminating evidence and research findings
Research Dissemination.description: Dissemination through websites here refers to traditional news stories and blogs whose main purpose is to share information and not to generate a conversation.

paragraphs: The Evidence Gap Map could just as easily be called the “Evidence Map”, meaning that it is a visual representation of existing evidence, using a matrix of USAID’s conceptualization of research for development activities and desired outcomes. We hope that by compiling this evidence in one place with a number of filter and search features, we will help facilitate the use of evidence.

The “gap” in the title is referring to understanding where there is good evidence in the matrix and where there are holes in our knowledge base and understanding. As users interact with the evidence gap map and the filters, they will be able to visually see where there is knowledge and where additional investments in research and evaluation might be warranted to further build the evidence base. The map was designed for a primary audience of USAID technical staff and program designers.
